discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Note: By default, dig looks for the "A" record of the domain specified, but you can specify other records also.

In a Linux system the first stage of the boot process is a hardware test using the BIOS. Once the hardware test is completed, control is passed to UEFI to begin the first-stage Linux boot process.
To which of the following categories does UEFI belong?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) is newer firmware technology that haslargely replaced BIOS by bringing with it several key advantages.

It's the only way

Which of the following commands replaces the old command service named stop?

questions.question_text:
A security administrator must use a password and a token to log in to the server.
Which of the following processes does this describe?

comments.content:
Specifically, from the link provided:
The public key is uploaded to a remote server that you want to be able to log into with SSH. The key is added to a special file within the user account you will be logging into called ~/.ssh/authorized_keys.

discussion.content:
I think Answer should be A. authorized keys. 

Per the provided reference link you place the contents from id_rsa.pub into the authorized_keys file

Selected Answer: C
The RSA key pair has to be generated first. the public key is saved locally in /home/[username]/.ssh/id_rsa.pub. The ssh-copy-id utility copies the public key and stores in the ~/.ssh/authorized_keys file on the system you are remoting in to.

The way the question is written, both answers are viable. However, as a process, the key is first added to the user's id_rsa.pub file.

CompTIA Linux+ Study Guide: Exam XK0-004, 4th Edition. Pg 462â€“464.

Selected Answer: A
The answer is A
https://www.ssh.com/ssh/authorized_keys/
Id_rsa.pub is the key and it is copied to (A.) authorized keys
A is correct authorized_keys is the file on the TARGET system that get appended with public key of the remote user

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
Why are the answers all wrong? What is the issue? Is it because they don't us to learn the correct thing? Crazy World.

Correct Answer: A. authorized_keys

Even in the link provided states: 

The public key is uploaded to a remote server that you want to be able to log into with SSH. The key is added to a special file within the user account you will be logging into called ~/.ssh/authorized_keys.

y default, the private key is stored in ~/.ssh/id_rsa and the public key is stored in ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub

The public key can be safely copied to other systems and appended to ~/.ssh/authorized_keys on those systems.

comments.content: unless he means which file generated should be pushed to the remote host then that would be the .pub. question is rather unclear

discussion.content: id_rsa is just the deafult name right? so that is the file but like you guys said it needs to be added to .ssh/authorized_keys

The authorized_keys file in SSH specifies the SSH keys that can be used for logging into the user account for which the file is configured. It is a highly important configuration file, as it configures permanent access using SSH keys and needs proper management.

The default configuration in most SSH implementations allows users to deploy new authorized keys for themselves and anyone they like. Such access is permanent, and may bypass privileged access management systems.

https://www.ssh.com/ssh/authorized_keys/

questions.question_text: A Linux systems administrator wants the ability to access systems remotely over SSH using RSA authentication. To which of the following files should the RSA token be added to allow this access?
